title: HBO swept the Emmys – but the rise in SVOD popularity is likely to change that in 2020
text:
This is an excerpt from a story delivered exclusively to Business Insider Intelligence Digital Media Briefing subscribers.

To receive the full story plus other insights each morning, click here.

Premium cablers and streaming services once again led Emmys wins by network in 2019, per Deadline. Overall, HBO won the most Emmys out of all networks nominated, with 34 total wins, followed by Netflix (27) and Amazon Prime Video (15).

Business Insider Intelligence

By comparison, traditional broadcast networks lagged, and NBC was the only broadcaster to take home any primetime Emmys wins: Overall, NBC took seven wins (with two for primetime), followed by CBS (four), Fox (four), The CW (four), and ABC (one).

It could become harder for HBO to maintain that dominance as Netflix, Amazon, and now Apple invest in developing high-quality original content for their platforms. Last year marked the first time in 17 years that HBO didn't win the most Emmys, tying the race with Netflix with 23 total wins.

Although HBO continued to lead the race this year, two of the shows that enabled the premium cable outlet to dominate — "Game of Thrones" and "Veep" — are ending their runs, after generating a significant number of nominations and wins for the network. This year, "Game of Thrones" scored 32 total nominations, the most noms of any program in a single year, and also topped total wins by a program (10).

In the course of its eight seasons, "Game of Thrones" has accounted for 161 total nominations. HBO losing its top-performing shows gives deep-pocketed giants like Netflix, Amazon, and Apple an opportunity to take more Emmys ground from the premium cable giant, which could translate to greater cultural cachet and subscriber growth.

The shift in top Emmy-winning networks is additional proof that linear TV networks will increasingly no longer be where the highest value content is distributed. In recent years, Netflix and other streaming giants including Amazon and Hulu have made inroads into awards that had been long dominated by traditional broadcast and cable networks.

Further, we could see the network leaderboard change as media companies themselves launch direct-to-consumer streaming services like Disney+, HBO Max, and Peacock where they'll feature original series, which could lure nominations. That would represent a significant transfer of cultural attention, investment, and talent, in which media companies will increasingly put their highest value content in direct-to-consumer environments rather than on linear TV networks.

If awards shows continue to indicate that the best content can't be found on traditional television, viewer migration to streaming could accelerate. Cord-cutting is still on the rise — about 2 million US TV households have cut the cord so far in 2019 — and about 60 million TV households will be cordless by 2024, per a Roku study.

If content is king, awards nominations and wins can be indicators of who holds power in the media and cultural landscape — clout that could eventually translate to greater defections from traditional TV as viewers migrate to premium services to access the most compelling shows.

description: HBO swept the 2019 Emmys – a feat that will become more challenging as Netflix, Amazon, and Apple continue developing high-quality original content.
